2. Wait loading @popular
3. Press install on any extention
4. Nothing happened, after 10 minutes waiting

my proxy setup is (from user's settings.json):

"https.proxy": "https://user:pass@webproxy:3128/",

data.title: Test: 'Variable paging'
data.body:
Test for #9537:
- [x] macOS - **@joaomoreno**
- [x] windows - **@kieferrm**

Previously large data structures (Array, Buffer, Map, Set) were broken into "chunks" in the debug extension. Starting with VS Code 1.4 this is done on the VS Code side so all the debug extensions will benefit from this.

Write or use a js/ts program with an array/buffer/map/set with more than 100 items and verify:
- data structures with a large number of children are displayed in chunks (these chunks are displayed collapsed and the children are fetched lazily on expand).
- Array, Buffer, Map, and Set also display programmatically added named properties.  
- you can inspect these large data structures in: the VARIABLES view, WATCH expressions, REPL, and hover

data.title: Integrated Terminal fails to display color prompt on Debian, Ubuntu, Mint
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 (Commit e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty), Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial), Debian 8.4 (Jessie), Linux Mint 18 (Sarah)
## Steps to Reproduce
1. Open VS Code.
2. Press `Ctrl-backtick` to open integrated terminal.
3. Observe whether the terminal prompt is colored or not.
## Details

On Debian-based systems (Debian, Ubuntu, Linux Mint), the default `.bashrc` in users' home folders sets the prompt to `(username)@(hostname):(current working directory)$(space)`. Additionally, if the terminal is capable of displaying color, it uses terminal escapes to color the username and hostname green, and the current working directory blue. The way the default `.bashrc` detects a color-capable terminal is by looking at the value of the `$TERM` environment variable; if it is `xterm-color` or `xterm-256color`, the color prompt is used; otherwise, a black&white prompt is used.

And this is where VS Code comes into the picture. In [line 18 of `terminalProcess.js`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/9a7ec35a6adc97b7b611a9bdc6228eaea7c6be0d/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalProcess.js#L18) (link is to the current `master` branch of VS Code as of the time when I'm writing this issue report), VS Code looks for the file `/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm-256color`. If it is present, then the `name` variable is set to `xterm-256color`, otherwise it is set to `xterm`. It seems that `name` eventually ends up as the value of the `$TERM` environment variable.

And here is where there's a bit of a problem. On Debian, and distributions like Ubuntu and Mint that derive from Debian, there is no `/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm-256color` file. The Debian package that contains `xterm-256color` puts it in `/lib/terminfo/x/xterm-256color` instead. (There is also a `/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm+256color` file, but that one is not guaranteed to be installed on all systems since it is not marked as "essential". But the Debian `ncurses-base` package, which is marked as "essential" and therefore guaranteed to be installed on all systems, installs the `/lib/terminfo/x/xterm-256color` file).

Therefore, since `/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm-256color` doesn't exist, when VS Code opens an integrated terminal it sets `$TERM` to be `xterm` instead of `xterm-256color`. And then Debian's `.bashrc` says "Oh, this isn't a color-capable terminal, better not use the color prompt".

**Note about Linux Mint:** In Linux Mint 18, the `.bashrc` has been modified to also use a color prompt if `$TERM` is set to `xterm`. Therefore, also Visual Studio Code still sets `$TERM` to `xterm`, incorrectly stating that it is not color-capable, Mint 18 actually _ignores_ this and uses a color prompt _anyway_. However, other programs run from inside the integrated terminal may see the incorrect value of `$TERM` and choose not to display color when they could have, so it's still worth fixing this for Mint as well. Thankfully, Mint places its `xterm-256color` file in the same place as Debian and Ubuntu, so the suggested fix is the same for all of these distributions.
## Suggested fix

The `fs.existsSync('/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm-256color')` line in `src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalProcess.js` could instead be changed to check for two files instead of just one:

```
name = (fs.existsSync('/usr/share/terminfo/x/xterm-256color') || fs.existsSync('/lib/terminfo/x/xterm-256color')) ? 'xterm-256color' : 'xterm';
```

I have tested this change on Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty) and it has the desired effect: inside the integrated terminal, `$TERM` is now set to `xterm-256color` and the Bash prompt is now colored instead of black&white. I have not tested this on the other affected distributions, but there is no reason why it should not work there as well.

data.title: Should brackets follow a method or function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

When I use `tab` or `enter` to select a method or function. It may be better to auto insert pair of brackets after method or function name.

_before:_
**`console.log`**

And it should like this. _after:_
**`console.log(...);`** or **`console.log();`**

So other languages should also do.

Thinks a lot.

data.title: Sash on top of hover
Close tab {count}

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This API is mainly used for Vim right now. 

```
:tabc[lose][!] {count} Close tab page {count}.
```

Close No.{count} tab in current editor and keep editing in current active tab.

data.title: Better behavior of the View Bar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: any

In the view bar, the icons are ~~not~~ poorly highlighted whenever a view is selected (i.e. Git or Debug). ~~You are assuming that a user may associate the view title with the icon, which is not the case for new users, and even some experienced/distracted.~~ The high-contrast themes show an orange border which is clearly visible, but not other themes.

Besides that, whenever a icon is pressed twice, the view panel disappears. This is related to the first case: if the user is not sure about what view is selected, he/she will end pressing an icon twice and the panel will disappear, while it was expected just to switch views. In this case it would be clearer to have a dedicated collapse/expand button.

data.title: Undo/Redo adds a stop in between CHN Characters
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Put any Chinese characters (more than 1) in any file of vscode;
2.Press CTRL+Z to undo the action above;

Separate a single CHN character into 2, so we need to press double CTRL+Z in coding.

This is the main reason I still use Sublime Text

data.title: Integrated terminal error: bash: __git_ps1: command not found
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

When using a custom bash prompt for git, the first message in VS Code integrated terminal on show is:

`bash: __git_ps1: command not found`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Modify bash prompt (from .bash_profile):

```
# Change command prompt
source ~/git-prompt.sh
export GIT_PS1_SHOWDIRTYSTATE=1
# '\u' adds the name of the current user to the prompt
# '\$(__git_ps1)' adds git-related stuff
# '\W' adds the name of the current directory
export PS1="$green\u$purple\$(__git_ps1)$blue \W $ $reset"
```
1. Open integrated terminal in VS Code

Note: Config works fine in Terminal application.

data.title: odd behavior when editing command in internal console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 professional (64bit)

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  set the shell of internal console to git bash: `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe"`
2. enter a command like `abcd efgh hijk mnop`, but don't hit `enter` to execute it
3. use `left` and `right` arrow keys to move the cursor (repeat several times)
4. the command becomes something like `abccd efgh hijk mnop`

- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-28-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder that contains a folder
2. Say `foo` is the open folder which contains `bar`, right clicking `bar` in the explorer and selecting open containing folder will open `foo` not `bar`.

It does not open the currently opened vscode folder but the parent of the selected folder.

data.title: Variable paging: support object properties for arrays
data.body:
I've added protocol support for Variables and the variablesRequest to distinguish between indexed and named properties of an object. This makes it possible to show both types of properties like in this example:

![2016-07-24_23-59-07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/17086753/b2989d06-51fa-11e6-90e8-98be0fded40d.png)

The API works as follows:
- a Variable optionally returns an `indexVariables` and/or a `namedVariables` property.
- the `indexVariables` works like 'totalCount' before.
- an `namedVariables` indicates that the variable has 'named' properties (in addition to 'indexed' properties). In this case the frontend is expected to request both the 'named' properties and the 'indexed' properties. The 'named' properties are requested through the variableRequest with a filter attribute 'named'.

data.title: VSCode won't start on elementary OS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1-1468329898
- OS Version: elementary OS 0.3.2 Freya (based on Ubuntu 14.04)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install Visual Studio Code .deb package.
2. Try to run VS Code from the applications launcher or from the command line. The `code` command exits, but the application does not start.

Running `code --verbose` from the command line produces the following output:

```
Gtk-Message: Failed to load module "pantheon-filechooser-module"
Gtk-Message: Failed to load module "canberra-gtk-module"
bash: cannot set terminal process group (-1): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
```

It seems that Code is running silently in the background. After attempting to start VSCode a few times, here's what I see in System Monitor:

![screenshot from 2016-07-24 17 40 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1299370/17086655/d6e5fa4e-51c5-11e6-8363-3374b6eb2229.png)

Thanks in advance for your help! :)

data.title: Use global tasks.json before project based tasks.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new project and setup tasks.json.
2. Create a new projects and setup another tasks.json
3. Repeat for each project
4. I have a lot of csharp projects and having to copy paste tasks.json to each is cumbersome.
5. Could VSCode look for a tasks.json or tasks.{language}.json in a global directory eg. ~/.vscode/tasks that can be applied to projects?
6. If tasks.json exists locally then it uses that or it merges both files some how

data.title: Regions issue
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Regions must be in the same tab. It would be great to allow us to fold no matter if they are in the same tab or not.
![wrong](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4130008/17082018/93afe09a-5144-11e6-809b-345afabc7cc7.png)
![right](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4130008/17082019/95e419ee-5144-11e6-8e7f-1e5c435f0699.png)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a Script (C#)
2. Create a method
3. Create a region encapsulating the method (Must be at the same tabulation)
4. Region cannot be fold
5. Move the method using tab
6. Now you can fold the region

data.title: Opening a file randomly overwrites the file in the current tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file in a tab
2. Find a new file by pressing ⌘P and hit Enter

Based on (the phase of the moon?) the current tab will either be replaced by the new file, or the new file will be opened in a new tab.

When splits are involved, I literally have no idea where a file will be opened. Sometimes I'll hit ⌘-Enter to to try to open the file in a tab in my second split, but the same problem happens, the file in the second split will be randomly overwritten.

There are clearly some rules about tabs/splits I don't understand, but this is alien behavior compared to other editors. My mental model of how file handling is implemented in vscode is currently "random number generator."

data.title: gui: Output | Problems | Debug | Terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OSX Version: 10.11.6

Currently there are 5 consoles
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863731/17081087/f468ee18-5149-11e6-8b08-2828a0fa8922.png)

Where command pallet gets a special place on top.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863731/17081083/b55269b6-5149-11e6-816b-a8aa836098e6.png)

My personnel opinion it is that it can be organised into tabs. Currently if you want to switch between all 5 you will go insane without using hotkeys and because I have the memory capabilities comparable of a chicken I suggest to group them together in a tab like manner. Take for example edge, firefox, chrome, safari that organize all their consoles into tabs

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863731/17081089/1e44e1f6-514a-11e6-9236-e3b53e8d65ec.png)

~~If this get approved consider also to include the command pallet in there so you have a consistent look and feel.~~ Basically the following tabs that looks like this.

Output | Problems | Debug | Terminal ~~| Command Pallet~~ 

I think it will be more intuitive especially for beginners

EDIT: tab notification suggestions
- Output: buffer changed
- Debug: breakpoint hit
- Terminal: command finished / buffer changed
- Problems: new errors

data.title: Markdown extension enhancement (update on css change)
data.body: In addition to rerendering the markdown preview of a markdown file when the contents of the document change, it should also rerender when any of the associated styles (from `"markdown.styles"`) are modified. If I get time, I will attempt to take a stab at this.

data.title: register command wont work in extension host mode
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1
- OS Version:ubuntu 16.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. generate a extension development environment
2. change `registerCommand('extension.sayHello')` to `registerCommand('extension.test')` in both files package.json and extension.ts
3. run `npm run compile` to compile typescript
4. run extension host by pressing `f5`
5. in extension host press `f1` and type the name of  your command
6. get the error `no handler found for extension.test ...` error
   ![](http://i.imgur.com/QQwGkQ6.png)
   ![](http://i.imgur.com/3c4HWUP.png)
   ![](http://i.imgur.com/6ijyCEb.png)
   ![](http://i.imgur.com/AuFURzl.png)
